title: MAC VS PC
content:
I currently use a pc to design but am looking into getting a new computer.

What makes a mac better for designing than a pc?

I do web graphics so wouldn't it be a better idea to view my designs in windows (the os that more people will be using to view the page).

Would an old power mac g5 with a dualcore 2.3 processor be any good?  
Otherwise I am going to do a custom core i7 build.

It just seems that for the money I can get a much better pc, and I do not see how pixels look any better on a mac.

Please let me know your thoughts.
author: jfldesign

I'm with Ivan. For most users, there has been virtually no reason to keep waging the Holy OS Wars for a few years now (except some people seem to think it's fun).

That said, in the case of the original poster I can actually think of one good reason for a Mac: It's very easy now to run Windows on Mac as well, so you essentially get two OSes on one box – which is a definite advantage for testing web designs. (But this will only work remotely well if you get an Intel-based Mac, i.e. newer than a G5.) Your call to decide if that's worth the additional cost to you.

I think one of the main reasons to get a Mac if you're a designer is so you are more marketable when looking for jobs. I know it's not not necessarily the same elsewhere, but in the US, Macs are the standard for design. I've never been in an ad agency or in-house design department that used anything else. Sure, the programs are going to operate more or less the same, but really knowing the computer, especially in in-house design jobs where you're at places with IT departments that only know Windows, is a HUGE plus.

If you're just planning on working on your own, I suppose it doesn't matter much, but if you're looking for a job, or if you want to more easily collaborate with most other designers, the advantages become pretty clear.

While one can run OSX on a Windows PC, it's not officially supported (or even allowed).

As such, if you're a web developer, it's nice to have a Mac for that reason alone. You can easily test a wide range of browsers fairly easily.

That said, there aren't huge issues in the OSX browsers for the most part. You can install Safari on Windows easy enough and Firefox is pretty much the same.

Obviously, if you want to get into iPhone dev, having a Mac is a prerequisite.

"It just seems that for the money I can get a much better pc"

If that's how you feel, then there's your answer. It depends on your region and how much effort one wants to put into DIY. When I comparison shop, I don't usually find the Macs to be more much more expensive (if at all) for what I'm getting. You can definitely get cheaper PCs, of course, but rarely will they have the same specs/niceties.

I use both all the time and if you really need to ask 'Mac vs. PC' then it really doesn't matter to you and/or you're just trolling for the sport of it. If you don't need to ask Mac Vs. PC it'd because you've used both and know the answer already.

I have both a PC and a Mac. Which do I prefer for general use? The PC. Which do I prefer for creative use? The Mac.

PC: Great for general use because almost all software is developed for PCs. The only software I can think of that I would use that isn't for PC is Adobe Aperture. Also, the only IM program I use is MSN, which as far as I know isn't available for Mac.

Mac: Switch on a Mac, and you forget that you're using a computer. For those that have never used a Mac, you won't understand this until you use one. Macs stay out of the way, and let you get on with what you're doing. However, as the OP has already stated, you do need to pay A LOT to get a Mac that runs current software blindingly fast.

The latest price drop combined with the awesome hardware specs had me order an iMac last week _pronto_. (The smallest model, actually -- 27" is a bit ... well, large.)

Programming under Windows is a breeze; I can kick out a console based program in mere minutes. I don't think that's quite possible on a Mac (suspiciously oogling XCode). On the other hand, I like the odd challenge, and I do look forward on Macifying some of my programs, such as [FontImage](http://web.archive.org/web/20100131130108/http:/typophile.com/node/45299).

Design-wise, it'll take some time to gather a same set of tools as I have now at my command, and _then_ get used to mouse-ing through dialogs, rather than hitting tab and hotkeys ...

Hi,

Firstly - you seem to have come under fire for asking an inappropriate question in a forum based around typography...

This question is dead my friend - It does still get peoples blood pumping though and for all the people shouting you down in here - you did get a good response.

For me- you answered the question yourself. - YOU DO 3D

I do alot of 3D - high end arch viz etc - The only option for me it so to use PC.  
I simply cannot do what I need to do on a Mac.

Macs are great - no question -  
I am an architect and have refused to work at some high profile offices because I walked in to find a white office full of Macs and people wearing Thick Black Glasses claiming Form Z was the pinnacle of 3D media creation -

A PC with all its niggles and quirks once set up the way I like it does everything I need.

3D - yep -get bags of Ram - if you can build yourself - make sure your bits are compatible - On paper this stuff should all work. In practice you will find bits don't always sit nicely together - I spent a year once with a self build running a dual processor pc on a single chip because I had all sorts of problems connecting to the internet - it was only 1 year later i was able to work out that USB modems with my mobo meant high voltage across the mobo and a shut down.

Once I got a modem that connected with RJ45 problem solved. Its not always this simple.  
I have had issues with ATI GPU's and I have had endless issues with AMD chips - I like you am into Intel

AMD for me is again not an option - I simply don't trust it.

The old - Macs are better for GFX argument (which usually comes from some tool with a 70's fro and a pair of jesus sandals underclad with brown socks - seams showing on the outside and all) IS DEAD - this was down to colour repro a long time back and Gamut etc etc.

I use a PC i have worked in IT retail in the past - i know both  
I made my choice and its nothing to do with the cache of owning a Mac -

If a client wanted me because of what i had in my bag and not what I have in my head then I don't want to work with them.

FLAME SUIT ON ~(MAYBE)

James

Everyone knows design work is more creative on a Mac sheesh!!

I'm actually a fairly recent convert. I too do a lot of motion work (3d and After Effects) which (in the past) meant that PC was the way to roll. Not any more though. I'm all for Mac.

I also do a lot of print work - and still believe Macs handle larger files better. That said, and this is the major thing I think...none of the PCs I've used have come from a complete dealer (i.e, Dell etc) - where everything is put in the box knowing it all works together.

I've always found PCs to be very niggly - particularly when you've just acquired it. All sorts of peripheral issues etc. Where as, my experience with Macs has been (mostly) really straight forward.

THAT said, in the future I'll being putting on PCs for dedicated 3d work. Their price point just can't be beaten - particularly for a render farm.
